question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Find all real numbers $x$ such that \[3 \le \frac{x}{2x-5} < 8.\](Give your answer in interval notation.)
inference:
We split this inequality into two separate inequalities:
\begin{align*}
3 &\le \frac{x}{2x-5} \\
\frac{x}{2x-5} &< 8.
\end{align*}We solve the first inequality.  Multiplying both sides by $2x - 5,$ we get \[3(2x - 5) \le x.\]This simplifies to $6x - 15 \le x,$ so $5x \le 15,$ or $x \le 3.$  We also need $2x - 5 \neq 0,$ so $x \neq \frac{5}{2}.$

Now we solve the second inequality.  Multiplying both sides by $2x - 5,$ we get \[x < 8(2x - 5).\]This simplifies to $x < 16x - 40,$ so $39 < 15x,$ or $x > \frac{13}{5}.$  We also need $2x - 5 \neq 0,$ so $x \neq \frac{5}{2}.$

Combining our solutions, we see that the solution set is $x \in \boxed{\left( \frac{13}{5}, 3 \right]}.$
ground_truth:
We work on the two parts of the given inequality separately. First, $3 \le \frac{x}{2x-5}$ is equivalent to \[0 \le \frac{x}{2x-5} - 3 = \frac{x - 3(2x-5)}{2x-5} = \frac{-5x + 15}{2x-5}.\]Making a sign table, we have:  \begin{tabular}{c|cc|c} &$-5x+15$ &$2x-5$ &$\frac{-5x+15}{2x-5}$ \\ \hline$x<\frac{5}{2}$ &$+$&$-$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$\frac{5}{2}<x<3$ &$+$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$x>3$ &$-$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]\end{tabular}Therefore, the inequality holds when $\tfrac52 < x < 3,$ as well as the endpoint $x = 3,$ which makes the right-hand side zero. The solution set to the first inequality is $(\tfrac52, 3].$

Second, $\frac{x}{2x-5} < 8$ is equivalent to \[\frac{x}{2x-5} - 8 = \frac{x - 8(2x-5)}{2x-5} = \frac{-15x + 40}{2x-5} < 0.\]Making another sign table, we have: \begin{tabular}{c|cc|c} &$-15x+40$ &$2x-5$ &$\frac{-15x+40}{2x-5}$ \\ \hline$x<\frac{5}{2}$ &$+$&$-$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$\frac{5}{2}<x<\frac{8}{3}$ &$+$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$x>\frac{8}{3}$ &$-$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]\end{tabular}It follows that the inequality holds when either $x < \tfrac52$ or $x > \tfrac83.$

The intersection of this solution set with $(\tfrac52, 3]$ is $\boxed{(\tfrac83, 3]},$ which is the solution set for both inequalities combined.

There might be an error in the solution above because of lack of understanding of the question. Please correct the error, if any, and rewrite the solution. Only output the final solution \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
inference: The solution is correct.  The error in the solution is that it is stated that the solution set is  $x \in \boxed{\left( \frac{13}{5}, 3 \right]}.$  This is incorrect because the solution set should include all values of $x$ that satisfy both inequalities.  The correct solution set is $x \in \boxed{\left( \frac{13}{5}, 3 \right)}.$
ground_truth:
We work on the two parts of the given inequality separately. First, $3 \le \frac{x}{2x-5}$ is equivalent to \[0 \le \frac{x}{2x-5} - 3 = \frac{x - 3(2x-5)}{2x-5} = \frac{-5x + 15}{2x-5}.\]Making a sign table, we have:  \begin{tabular}{c|cc|c} &$-5x+15$ &$2x-5$ &$\frac{-5x+15}{2x-5}$ \\ \hline$x<\frac{5}{2}$ &$+$&$-$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$\frac{5}{2}<x<3$ &$+$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$x>3$ &$-$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]\end{tabular}Therefore, the inequality holds when $\tfrac52 < x < 3,$ as well as the endpoint $x = 3,$ which makes the right-hand side zero. The solution set to the first inequality is $(\tfrac52, 3].$

Second, $\frac{x}{2x-5} < 8$ is equivalent to \[\frac{x}{2x-5} - 8 = \frac{x - 8(2x-5)}{2x-5} = \frac{-15x + 40}{2x-5} < 0.\]Making another sign table, we have: \begin{tabular}{c|cc|c} &$-15x+40$ &$2x-5$ &$\frac{-15x+40}{2x-5}$ \\ \hline$x<\frac{5}{2}$ &$+$&$-$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$\frac{5}{2}<x<\frac{8}{3}$ &$+$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$x>\frac{8}{3}$ &$-$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]\end{tabular}It follows that the inequality holds when either $x < \tfrac52$ or $x > \tfrac83.$

The intersection of this solution set with $(\tfrac52, 3]$ is $\boxed{(\tfrac83, 3]},$ which is the solution set for both inequalities combined.
